citation.article-title: Luteimonas marina sp. nov., isolated from seawater.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Luteimonas marina sp. nov.
Luteimonas marina (ma.ri′na. L. fem. adj. marina of or belonging to the sea, marine).
Cells are Gram-negative, aerobic, non-flagellated (Supplementary Fig. S2, in IJSEM Online), rod-shaped, 0.5–0.6 μm in width and about 1.4–2.0 μm in length.
Cells grow on TSA, NA and MA, but not on MacConkey agar.
Colonies on TSA at 30 °C (pH 7) are light yellow, circular, convex, smooth, opaque, with entire edges and approximately 1.5–2.0 mm in diameter after 4 days incubation.
Growth occurs at 20–42 °C (optimum, 30 °C), but not at 45 °C.
Growth occurs at pH 6–10 (optimum, pH 8.0), but not at pH 5.0 or 11.0.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0–1 % (w/v) NaCl.
Does not grow anaerobically on MA or TSA.
Accumulates poly-β-hydroxybutyrate granules.
Oxidase- and catalase-positive.
Casein, l-tyrosine and Tween 20 are hydrolysed, but DNA, xylan and starch are not.
Acid is not produced from 0.5 % (w/v) glucose or maltose.
Negative for haemolysis of sheep blood and utilization of citrate.

The following carbon sources are utilized (positive with the Biolog GN2 system): N-acetyl-d-galactosamine, alaninamide, l-alanyl glycine, l-arabinose, cellobiose, α-cyclodextrin, dextrin, gentiobiose, d-glucose, l-glutamic acid, glycyl l-aspartic acid, glycyl l-glutamic acid, α-hydroxybutyric acid, maltose, melibiose, l-proline, l-serine, succinic acid and Tween 40.

Utilization of the following carbon sources is weakly positive (Biolog GN2 system): acetic acid, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, d-alanine, bromosuccinic acid, d-glucose 6-phosphate, α-ketobutyric acid, pyruvic acid methyl ester, l-ornithine, l-threonine and Tween 80.
Other substrates of the Biolog GN2 system are not utilized.

Positive reactions (API 20E and 20NE systems) are obtained for β-galactosidase, gelatinase, aesculin hydrolysis and assimilation of N-acetylglucosamine, arabinose, citrate, glucose, malate and maltose, but negative reactions for arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, tryptophan deaminase, urease, H2S production, production of acetoin and indole, oxidation of amygdalin, arabinose, inositol, mannitol, rhamnose, sorbitol and sucrose, fermentation of glucose, and assimilation of adipate, caprate, gluconate, mannitol, mannose and phenylacetate.

Positive (API ZYM) for activities of N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, acid phosphatase, alkaline phosphatase, α-chymotrypsin, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase, leucine arylamidase, α-mannosidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, trypsin and valine arylamidase, but negative for cystine arylamidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-fucosidase and lipase (C14).

Susceptible to (μg per disc, unless otherwise indicated): amikacin (30), chloramphenicol (30), erythromycin (15), kanamycin (30), nalidixic acid (30), polymyxin B (300 IU), tetracycline (30) and vancomycin (30), but resistant to ampicillin (10), gentamicin (10), penicillin (10 IU) and streptomycin (10).
Additional physiological characteristics are given in Table 1.
Major fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0 and iso-C17 : 1ω9c (the complete fatty acid composition is given in Table 2).
Ubiquinone-8 is the predominant quinone.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 67.6 %.
The type strain, FR1330T (=KCTC 12327T=JCM 12488T=IMSNU 60306T), was isolated from seawater near Ganghwa Island, the Republic of Korea.
